headline: Apple’s iPhone Could Cost Up to 26% More. PCs and Other Hardware Will Soar, Too.
summary: FEATURE  Tech hardware prices will go higher—much, much higher—because of the Trump tariffs, new numbers from New Street Research show. The increases, as calculated by analyst Pierre Ferragu: Computers: 28% to 35%; high-end smartphones: 21% to 26%; computer servers and networking devices: 25% to 31%; and telecom equipment: 9% to 12%.

headline: Why Shares of Apple Are Getting Hammered Today
summary: Shares of consumer tech giant Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) traded over 5.6% lower today as of 12:52 p.m. ET, extending its sell-off after President Donald Trump issued far-reaching tariffs late last week.  Wedbush analyst Dan Ives lowered his price target on the stock in a research report issued yesterday, while maintaining a bullish rating.  Ives, who has long been bullish on big tech stocks in the "Magnificent Seven," has issued several sobering research notes in light of Trump's tariffs.

Ives, who has long been bullish on big tech stocks in the "Magnificent Seven," has issued several sobering research notes in light of Trump's tariffs.

headline: Tariff storm ravages Magnificent Seven as Apple nears one-year low
summary: The "Magnificent Seven" stocks sank on Monday, extending a market rout that has wiped off around $2 trillion from their combined value as investors worry about the financial fallout of U.S. President Donald Trump's global tariff war.  The latest slide followed cuts in price target for Apple and Tesla shares from one of Wall Street's most bullish tech analysts, Dan Ives, who warned of a "tariff economic armageddon".  The cuts came as Trump doubled down on tariffs on Sunday, telling investors to endure the consequences and ruling out trade talks with China for now.

raw.headline: Tariff storm ravages Magnificent Seven as Apple nears one-year low

The cuts came as Trump doubled down on tariffs on Sunday, telling investors to endure the consequences and ruling out trade talks with China for now.

headline: Tesla & Apple price target cuts, Spirit CEO steps down
summary: Brad Smith and Madison Mills take a closer look at some of the trending tickers on Yahoo Finance in premarket trading on Morning Brief. Tesla (TSLA) shares fall after longtime bull, Wedbush analyst Dan Ives, cut his price target to $315 from $550, citing China tariffs and softer demand. Apple (AAPL) stock is on the decline after the Wedbush analyst also lowered his Apple price target to $250 from $325 due to the impact of tariffs. Spirit Airlines (SAVEQ) CEO Ted Christie steps down after the company exited bankruptcy protection as part of a private deal. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

Apple (AAPL) stock is on the decline after the Wedbush analyst also lowered his Apple price target to $250 from $325 due to the impact of tariffs. Spirit Airlines (SAVEQ) CEO Ted Christie steps down after the company exited bankruptcy protection as part of a private deal. headline: Dan Ives Calls Import Tariffs "Armageddon." Should You Really Buy Tech Stocks Now?
summary: Investors piled into technology stocks over the past couple of years on optimism that artificial intelligence (AI) could become the next great revolution.  Unsurprisingly, tech stocks led gains in the Nasdaq Composite (NASDAQINDEX: ^IXIC), but they also drove the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJINDICES: ^DJI) and the S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) higher.  Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) and Palantir Technologies posted the top performances in those two indexes, respectively, last year.
